results.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer and Ben Protess
results.title: What We Learned From the Trump Indictment
results.abstract: The indictment said the former president had illegally kept documents concerning “United States nuclear programs; potential vulnerabilities of the United States and its allies to military attack; and plans for possible retaliation in response to a foreign attack.”

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Space and Astronomy;Books and Literature;Mennonite Churches;Religion and Belief;Writing and Writers;Pluto (Dwarf Planet);Gingerich, Owen;Copernicus, Nicolaus;International Astronomical Union;Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory
results.title: Owen Gingerich, Astronomer Who Saw God in the Cosmos, Dies at 93
results.abstract: He wrote and lectured widely, often on the theme that religion and science were not incompatible. He also chased down 600 copies of Copernicus’s landmark book.

media.caption: The astronomer Owen Gingerich in 1972. In his long career at Harvard, he was known as a lively and entertaining lecturer.

results.title: Ready for a Nice, Soothing Bath? Just Head to the Backyard.
results.abstract: Cheaper than pools and more private than hot tubs, the bathtub is leaving the bathroom and has designs on your garden, or even your treehouse.

results.title: Novak Djokovic Captures the French Open and a 23rd Grand Slam Title
results.abstract: Djokovic beat Casper Ruud to win the men’s singles championship, passing Rafael Nadal for the most major tournament titles in the Open era.

media.caption: Novak Djokovic, who has separated himself from his rivals, clutched the French Open trophy. At one point on Sunday, he cried into it.
